# Question

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Sure! Here is a possible implementation of the `clean_column` function in Julia:
```
function clean_column(col)
    col = lowercase(col) # lowercase the column name
    col = replace(col, r"\s+", "_") # strip leading and trailing spaces
    col = replace(col, r"-", "_") # replace hyphens with underscores
    return col # return the cleaned column name
end
```
This function uses the `lowercase`, `replace`, and `rfind` functions from the standard library to perform the desired transformations on the input column name. The `r"\s+"` pattern matches one or more whitespace characters (spaces, tabs, line breaks, etc.), and the `replace` function replaces them with an underscore. Similarly, the `r"-"` pattern matches a hyphen, and the `replace` function replaces it with an underscore.

Note that this implementation assumes that the input column name is a string. If the input is a symbol or any other type of data, you may need to modify the function accordingly.
